intro: Phymatodes malacodon, commonly known as the red sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its slender, branched stems and showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in summer. Its leaves are simple, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, giving them a fuzzy appearance. Phymatodes malacodon thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in desert and semi-arid environments.
